abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: The study explores the inter-relations between green and renewable energy and carbon risk. Key market participants with varying time horizons include traders, authorities, and other financial entities. This research examines these relationships and frequency dimensions from February 7, 2017, to June 13, 2022, using novel multivariate wavelet analysis approaches, such as partial wavelet coherency and partial wavelet gain. The multiple coherencies between green bond, clean energy, and carbon emission futures imply that these regions were situated at low frequencies (relating to approximately 124-day frequency) and run from the beginning of 2017 to the beginning of 2018, in the first half of 2020, and from the beginning of 2022 to the end of the sample. The relationship between the solar energy index, envitec biogas, biofuels, geothermal energy, and carbon emission futures, is significant in the low-frequency band starting from early 2020 to middle 2022 and in the high-frequency band starting from early 2022 to middle 2022. Our research demonstrates the partial coherencies between these indicators during the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The partial coherency between the S&P green bond index and carbon risk suggests that carbon risk pushes anti-phase connectedness. The partial phase difference S&P global clean energy index and carbon emission futures (from early April 2022 to the end of April 2022) recommend that indicators are in-phase with carbon risk pushing and the phase (from early May 2022 to middle June 2022), suggesting that carbon emission futures are in-phase with S&P global clean energy index pushing.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Energy security and ecological sustainability have become integral to modern economies (Arslan et al. 2022; Jackman and Moore 2021; Khan et al. 2022). Khan and Hou (2021) reveal the significance of energy security and environmental sustainability in terms of pollution reduction by using a database of thirty members of the International Energy Agency (IEA). Additionally, ecological sustainability plays a key role in the pursuit of sustainable development goals (Zakari et al. 2022a). Energy security and environmental sustainability play a critical role in alleviating poverty (Taghizadeh-Hesary et al. 2022) and sustainable economic growth (Arslan et al. 2022). In the literature, there is a vast number of empirical studies on determinants of environmental sustainability, such as the role of green innovation (Zakari et al. 2022a); abundant energy resources (Zakari et al. 2022b) and alternative and nuclear energy (Khan et al. 2022); economic growth, international trade, and clean energy investment (Lyu et al. 2021); industrial value-added, capital formation, urbanization, population growth, and biocapacity (Yang and Khan 2021); the energy consumption, tourism growth (Khan and Hou 2021), or the partnership between countries (Tawiah et al. 2021). Recent studies have demonstrated the importance of sustainable oil consumption and production in promoting environmental health (Zakari et al. 2022b). Although scholars have given considerable attention to both the determinants and influences of energy security and environmental sustainability, there are still a number of areas that require further investigation (Statistical Review of World Energy).

The effects of climate change are felt throughout all economic sectors today. Consequently, it contributes to the occurrence of natural disasters that have detrimental effects on the functioning of the economy. As natural disasters increase in number and intensity, millions of lives are lost, capital stock is destroyed, and economic instability is created. According to several studies, unpredictable changes in the climate, along with continued temperature increases, are predicted to reduce the world economy by 10% by 2021 (Guo et al. 2021). The responsibilities of giant hedge fund managers are heightened under these circumstances as they are exposed to greater risk. However, fluctuations can also create many new opportunities. As a result, many governments around the world have promised to decrease CO2 emissions and to lower the rate of increase of temperature levels in order to limit global warming. Renewable energy, green bonds, and carbon pricing are all emerging potential financial opportunities.

As a result of the industrial revolution, fossil fuels are depleting at an increasing rate. A major contributor to global warming and climate change is greenhouse gas emissions (GHG), the most hazardous waste produced by burning fossil fuels. The devastating natural disasters that have occurred for many consecutive years have awakened humankind. The search for renewable energy sources has begun in order to replace fossil fuels. In addition to the wind, water, solar, biomass, and wave energy, among others, the energy industry faces many challenges in its quest to achieve sustainable development and reduce carbon emissions. The commitment to these goals is recognized in the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement and the UN Sustainable Development Goals. Aiming to be the leader in the renewable energy sector creates fierce competition among investors. After 2015, solar and wind energy achieved record growth with a two-fold jump. It is predicted that wind capacity will keep rising at a pace of approximately 14% per year and that solar capacity will grow at a rate of around 18% per year. If these growth rates are as high as predicted, more green capital will be required in this industry, which will lead to green economic growth.

As a result, the question arises: what source of capital will be able to finance the fledgling green economy to help economies achieve the goal of being eco-friendly? A green bond is used to finance or refinance eco-friendly projects by utilizing bond issuance funds. Since the European Investment Bank issued the first green bond in 2007, they have grown in popularity as a substitute for fixed-income securities. In the literature, it is more likely that the green bond is a two-edged sword. On the one hand, they assist in combating climate change by financing green initiatives. On the other hand, they provide a chance for shareholders to enhance their portfolios and curtail their jeopardies (Tiwari et al. 2022). In addition, in 2019, total green bond sales hit a new high of US$258.9 billion, representing a 51% increase over 2018. The majority of the revenues (38%) were utilized in the energy industry. Renewable energy and energy efficiency are funded by the majority of the earnings from green bonds. The issue is the impact of carbon risk on the volatility of the renewable energy sector when green bonds appear.

In this study, we examine the relationship between carbon risk and the volatility of the energy sector. The energy sector may be affected by changes in manufacturers’ energy sources, especially dramatic swings in carbon prices (Guo et al. 2021; Wang et al. 2021). The trend and level of volatility spillover into the carbon and the energy sector are highly time-varying (Chevallier et al. 2018). Notably, when these indicators are hit by crises, and the impact is stronger than in other times, there is a systemic break. More recently, authors have paid attention to the connectedness between different markets during the Russia-Ukraine conflict. For example, Hossein Motlagh et al. (2020) reveals that the Russia-Ukraine conflict challenged the achievements and potential growth of the clean energy industry around the world. This crisis disrupted the growth of this industry and brought the process back to scratch. Therefore, more empirical studies are needed to help the world better understand the impact of the Russia-Ukraine conflict on the renewable energy market. Recently, Liu et al. (2021) discovered that the risks produced by the Russia-Ukraine conflict had had a greater impact on the returns and fluctuations of green power equities than the uncertainty caused by the Global Financial Crisis (GFC). However, the above studies have not specifically estimated the spillover impact between carbon risk and the renewable energy sector during the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

In addition, governments are taking strict measures to manage fossil fuels, which may reduce the impact of carbon risk on the energy sector (Lazarus and van Asselt 2018). The power of fossil fuel companies worldwide is threatening the development of green bonds. Their effects reduce the capital of the renewable energy sector. To attract investors and capture market share from fossil fuels, the renewable energy sector needs to reduce production costs. Carbon pricing is added to the overall production costs of coal or other energy industries. Eventually, the competitiveness of fossil fuels will be seriously reduced, and renewable energy will become more competitive. Indeed, Hanif et al. (2021) found substantial and considerable spillover between CO2 emissions and the renewable energy sector in the short and long term. They found that there is a dependency and connection between carbon pricing and renewable energy stock, regardless of the time horizon. Their research revealed a positive connection between carbon costs and green power supplies. Our paper aims to bring carbon pricing into the dynamic framework between green bonds and renewable energy stocks. We also provide an overall view of these dynamic interactions.

There are very few studies on the effects of carbon risk on global equity prices, green bonds, and nonrenewable and renewable energy stocks, particularly during uncertain times like the Russia-Ukraine conflict, or studies on the positioning of carbon pricing in this connection. One of the few studies in this field is by Balcılar et al. (2016), who investigated the risk spillover between energy futures prices and European carbon emission trading. The originality of our article is that it fills this void. Until now, particularly in light of the Russia-Ukraine conflict, no research has provided a detailed and comprehensive examination of the dynamic connectedness between the carbon price and the renewable energy sector. As a result, our article aims to explore the volatility spillover between the carbon price and the renewable energy sector. Our goals are to avoid rapid fluctuations in carbon prices, make the carbon price stable, and limit the negative impact of carbon risk on the energy market. Simultaneously, it promotes the protection of systemic financial risks in the renewable energy sector and ensures a green energy supply. In tough intervals, measures help nations flourish and survive by reducing the adverse consequences of the war problem on the petroleum sector as well as stabilizing the investment markets. This work addresses these literature gaps by utilizing innovative multivariate wavelet analysis (MWA) tools. These tools consist of partial wavelet gain and coherency to analyze the interrelationships and determine how they behave at various frequencies and how they evolve. Our decision to work with MWA was primarily based on three factors. First, we need to use a method for non-stationary data to explore carbon risk on global equity prices, green bonds, and nonrenewable and renewable energy stocks. Second, the issue of a short-time database can be dealt with by the MWA. Third, it is important to note that decisions relating to the development of environmental protection are always made in conjunction with long-term plans. A large-scale management strategy decision is neither quick nor easy. Due to this, from both angles, it is sensible to take into account the presence of short- and long-term decisions, which means that these relationships should be examined simultaneously at different frequencies. An easy way to accomplish this is through wavelet analysis. Wavelets are also useful for investigating time-varying relations in finance and economics.

Our paper makes at least three contributions to the literature. Using innovative multivariate wavelet analysis, we first examine the relationship between green bonds and renewable energy stocks. Second, we employ portfolio techniques by developing dynamic weighting schemes incorporating a new minimum connectedness portfolio. These techniques demonstrate how carbon risk affects the volatility of the renewable energy sector. Third, we investigate the effect of carbon pricing on the volatility of the renewable and nonrenewable sectors. Fourth, our study illustrates the robustness of these conclusions in the face of challenging market conditions, such as the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The findings reveal the heterogeneity of dynamic interconnectedness between assets influenced by global events.

The layout of the paper is arranged as follows. “Literature review” section presents a quick overview of recent research on the effects of carbon risk on the renewable energy sector volatility. “Data and methodology” section covers the data employed in this study and is devoted to the data analysis methods. “Remarked results” section presents and examines the findings, and “Conclusions”section ends the research and gives policy implications.

sec.title: Literature review
sec.p: Ali et al. (2023), Awan et al. (2022), and Khan and Hou (2021) contend that urbanization and economic growth are often sacrificed for environmental sustainability. The security of energy and the quality of the environment are harmed in order to achieve a higher level of economic development (Khan et al. 2021). Khan et al. (2021) demonstrate that energy consumption and economic growth are positively correlated, both in the short run and in the long run. Khan et al. (2021) analyze the effects of natural resources, energy consumption, and global uncertainties on environmental quality. There has been a recent finding that there is an association between energy intensity, financial development, and ecological sustainability in Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) countries by Khan et al. (2022) and in OECD countries by Khan et al. (2021). The causes and impacts of energy security and environmental sustainability have been examined in previous research, but they have not adequately taken into account the attendants of energy insecurity and environmental degradation. It is also important to note that there are channels through which environmental sustainability or other factors affecting the environment can be either signified or mitigated. As a critical issue to ensure energy security and ecological sustainability, our paper aims to demonstrate critical antecedents of energy security and ecological sustainability.

Carbon risk has received considerable attention as a result of the global movement against climate change. Carbon prices are becoming increasingly prevalent in the finance literature. Their interactions with nonrenewable and renewable energy equities and commodities have been the subject of extensive research. Based on the interaction between fossil fuel stocks and products, Asl et al. (2021) investigated the spreads and returns between the S&P global oil, natural gas, and crude oil indices, as well as other investment channels. The findings revealed that the renewable energy and oil indices receive the greatest ideal weights in their portfolio selection. The results also showed that green power stocks could be strong insurance against equity hazards with fossil fuel industries. On the oil market, for example, Ferrer et al. (2018) employed the time–frequency connectedness approach devised by Baruník and Křehlík (2018). They evaluated the dynamic connectedness between the US green power market and the oil market. Their research discovered significant connectedness in the short term but not in the long term. Nevertheless, the analysis found that crude oil prices did not influence the results of green power stocks. We confirm the findings of Henriques and Sadorsky (2008), who found a weak link between oil markets and green power markets in a vector autoregression (VAR) framework. On the other hand, Reboredo (2015) used a conditional value-at-risk (CoVaR) technique to discover the proportionality between the oil market and the green power market. These findings have consequences for investors in terms of portfolio selection. Based on the investor’s volatility in terms of portfolio choice and distribution, bioenergy becomes a significant asset that could provide upside potential. These papers differ from our current analysis in that they examine the relationship between crude oil and renewable energy equities. The current research also provides information supporting greater investment in green initiatives to help counter climate change. As such, we are interested in knowing whether green bonds and renewable energy stocks can be suitable portfolios. Our research answers the question of whether green bonds can function as a hedge for green power and carbon risk, especially during times of uncertainty such as COVID-19.

The risk of spillover is one of the major concerns with the relationship between carbon and the energy sector. Balcılar et al. (2016) examined the risks associated with energy futures prices and European carbon emission trading. There was significant volatility and time-varying risk conduction from the carbon price and also time-varying correlations. They also found volatility hedging effectiveness in the spot and futures parts of the emissions market. Volatility spillover was more complicated in multi-renewable energy sector systems than it is between the two sectors. Fuel cells and solar energy sectors were crucial to the risk distribution path, so they must be avoided. In addition, Jin et al. (2019) investigated the role of green bonds as an effective hedging mechanism for carbon pricing volatility. They assessed the hedging effect of green bonds. Previous research utilized all three of the DCC-APGARCH, DCC-T-GARCH, and DCC-GJR-GARCH models and the constant hedge ratio model. According to the analysis, the green bond index was always the best hedge for the carbon market. Reboredo (2015) verified the great variety of advantages of green bonds for stock and energy markets, but they had only a small impact on firm and treasury market investors.

The spillover impact between carbon and the energy sector varied over time and did not remain constant in Ji et al.'s (2018) study. Chen et al. (2021) found that the global carbon and energy sectors were dynamically intertwined. Wang et al. (2020) investigated the dynamic dependency between the global carbon price using the copula GARCH model and the general matching impact approach. They discovered a clear, dynamic connection between EUA and CER futures and spots. The MS-DCC-GARCH model was employed by Balcilar et al. (2016). Zhang (2016) used the GARCH model to investigate the dynamics of volatility spillovers between Europe’s carbon trading sector and the fossil energy market. Using a bivariate VAR-GARCH model, Dutta (2018) investigated the daily return and volatility relationship between EUA price and renewable energy equity returns. They found that EUA price changes had a positive effect on the renewable energy return. The findings revealed that emissions and green power prices in Europe had a substantial volatility connection. Moreover, a clear spillover impact between carbon and nonrenewable energy, with a time-varying and asymmetric strength and trend, was reported by Gong et al. (2023). The oil market has the most influence on the carbon sector. Spillover effects between the carbon and fossil fuel industries lasted approximately three weeks, gradually diminishing over time. Time-varying spillovers have the biggest impact, particularly when there is a one-week lag. Zhang et al. (2023) investigated the volatility spillover impact and dynamic correlation between China's emission quota and the fossil fuel industry. They used a DCC-GARCH model. The dynamic connection between the fossil fuel industry and carbon price time-varying tendency was small in the period under consideration. They found the prohibition of emission limits flows led to ineffective dynamic links between the two markets and low-cost transmission. These findings imply a reduction in future volatility spillover impacts and dynamic correlations.

The above literature demonstrates the interaction and links between green bonds, oil markets, commodities, and energy indices. The present work mostly analyzes the GARCH model to assess the spillover impact between carbon and energy sectors. However, this method cannot effectively examine the directional features of the spillover effect. Finally, most current literature addresses the volatility spillover impact using static models, but there is still a paucity of research on the dynamic spillover effect. Our research delves into an issue that previous studies have not noticed. We concentrate on the spillover impact of carbon futures and especially the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the volatility of the renewable energy sector.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: This paper uses the daily data on carbon emission futures (CEF), which are market-based systems aimed at reducing greenhouse gases, thus resolving global warming. The volatility of the energy sector is analyzed through green bonds (SPGB), clean energy (SPGTCLEN), wind energy (GWE), solar energy (SUNIDX), biogas, biofuels, and geothermal energy. Our time series refers to the time from February 7, 2017, to June 13, 2022. Our data sample period is marked by unexpected events like the COVID-19 pandemic crisis and the Russia-Ukraina conflict, which are predicted to cause the energy market to be more volatile (Ha 2022; Ha and Nham 2022). In the energy sector, we collect S&P Green Bond Index (SPGB), which is the market-weighted index used to reflect the worldwide green bond market. The Macerich Company Global Solar Energy Index Net Total Return (SUNIDX) aims to measure the results of solar energy firms in the world. Moreover, we also have S&P Global Clean Energy Index (SPGTCLEN). The ISE Global Wind Energy Index (GWE) measures public firms involved in the wind power industry based on examining their goods and services. Envitec biogas (BIOGAS) is the stock price of a Germany-based biogas plant construction company. A core sector index of the Green Economy Index called NASDAQ OMX Bio/Clean Fuels Index (GRNBIO) was created to measure businesses that produce plant-based fuels to remove petroleum-based fuels in transportation. A sub-index of the Green Economy Index called the NASDAQ OMX Geothermal Index (GRNGEO) is used to measure businesses that use geothermal energy to generate energy.

sec.title: Baseline results
sec.p:
A short overview based on our dataset is shown in Fig. 1. Figure 1(a) represents the pattern of the daily data for the indicators, such as carbon emission futures, green bond, clean energy, wind energy, solar energy, biogas, biofuels, and geothermal energy, and the wavelet power spectra are toward the right (Fig. 1(b)). Our sample is daily from February 7, 2017, to June 13, 2022. Carbon emission futures have increased, as seen on the left side of Fig. 1(a.1). This indicator increased significantly in February 2017 before declining significantly and remaining consistently positive through the end of 2019. In early 2020, we observed a significant increase in carbon emission futures due to the outbreak of COVID-19 before returning to the previous trend. Carbon emission futures reached a peak when the Ukraine-Russia conflict occurred on February 24, 2022. In contrast to the fluctuations of carbon emission trading, green bonds, clean energy, solar energy, biogas, clean fuels, and geothermal energy were relatively stable before 2020, as displayed in Fig. 1(a.2 to a.8). All the renewable energy reached a peak due to COVID-19 outbreak. Except in early 2020, the volatility of green bonds stayed at under 1% on average. These indicators remained stable in the second half of 2021 and spiked since the Ukraine-Russia conflict. In unusual events like the COVID-19 epidemic and the Ukraine-Russia conflict, the substantial volatility of carbon emission futures significantly affected renewable energy. Specifically, during the Ukraine-Russia conflict, the factories in Europe increase coal power generation to reduce the use of Russian gas. The carbon footprint of coal power generation will be much higher than gas power generation, increasing carbon emission futures demand. Moreover, the future of the renewable energy market is also being reshaped as the authorities realize the dangers of depending on Russia’s fossil fuels. The renewable energy market is receiving huge investments from European countries in an effort to diversify energy supplies.Fig. 1
Short overview data analysis. (a) Plot of carbon emission futures, green bond, clean energy, wind energy, solar energy, biogas, biofuels, and geothermal energy. (b) The power spectrum of a wavelet. The 5%/10% significance level indicates by the contour in black and gray. A black line represents the cone-of-influence or the area that is impacted by edge effects. Power is denoted by a color code that runs from blue (low efficiency) to red (high efficiency). The white lines depict the wavelet power spectrum’s maximum undulations

The wavelet power depicted by the figures on the right illustrates the size of the indicator’s variance at each cyclical wave frequency. Edge effects, which are unavoidable artifacts that emerge while calculating the continuous wavelet modification for a limited series, are significant in the area marked by the black conic line in plots of the wavelet power (COI); outside of this line, researchers would more cautiously evaluate the results. A color range from dark blue (low fluctuation) to red helps us identify the level of variability (high variability). Local maxima are shown in the power spectra by the white lines. Black outlines denote significance levels of 5%, whereas grey contours denote significance levels of 10%. These were calculated using the previously mentioned theoretical power distribution, with a flat spectrum used as the null. The wavelet power spectrum is shown in Fig. 1(b.1 through b.8). It is important to note that carbon emission futures have at least four main cycles. The fluctuation of the two cycles was concentrated at high frequencies in early 2019, early 2020, and early 2022. Green bonds had three dominant cycles. One cycle lasted three months from early 2020, while another was concentrated at low frequencies between January 2020 and July 2020. There was also a cycle that appeared in the middle of 2022. Regarding clean energy, wind energy, and solar energy, there were four cycles, and three of those cycles were concentrated at high frequencies. These indicators had two dominant cycles that coexisted simultaneously. One cycle was from 2020, while other cycles were concentrated in the second half of 2020. Regarding biogas, biofuels, and geothermal, there were cycles concentrated in the right of our sample at high frequencies in early 2020 and early 2022. Moreover, these indicators have some cycles that coexisted at low frequencies in early 2020 and early 2022. In unusual events like the COVID-19 epidemic and the Ukraine-Russia conflict, the strong volatility of geopolitical risks significantly affected renewable energy. Specifically, during the Ukraine-Russia conflict, European factories increased coal power generation to reduce the use of Russian gas. Moreover, the future of the renewable energy market is also being reshaped as the authorities realize the dangers of depending on Russia’s fossil fuels. The renewable energy market is receiving huge investments from European countries in an effort to diversify energy supplies. Previous studies, such as those by Balcilar et al. (2017) and Broadstock and Zhang (2019), have demonstrated that the interconnection of diverse commodities markets rises in uncertain periods, such as the global financial crisis (2007–2009).

The early study of the wavelet power spectra yielded a number of significant conclusions. However, there are few connections between the S&P clean energy index, solar energy index, S&P green bond index, envitec biogas index, biofuels index, and geothermal energy that may be seen. We can see in Fig. 2 when and at which frequency these interactions are strongest. The numerous coherencies between these indicators are estimated in this paper. During the time period under study, pertinent high-coherency zones exist. We find at least three zones with statistically significant coherency for the numerous correlations between green bonds, clean energy, and carbon emission futures, as shown in Fig. 2a. The most significant one spans from early 2017 to 2018 and is placed at low frequencies (equivalent to cycles with a periodicity of approximately 124 days). The two additional cycles were situated at low frequencies as well. Both cycles run from the beginning of 2022 through the conclusion of the sample, with one cycle running for the first half of 2020. Other cycles occurred at high frequencies and were quite modest. The numerous correlations between the solar energy index, envitec biogas, biofuels, geothermal energy, and carbon emission futures are shown in Fig. 2b. Additionally, at least four areas had statistically significant coherency, and they were only focused on the high-frequency range (6–12 days) from early 2022 to middle 2022 and the low-frequency range (12–124 days) from early 2020 to middle 2022. Three areas coexisted during the first half of 2022. Our findings suggest that renewable energy volatility has a significant negative impact on the environment by focusing on the relationships between these parameters. Furthermore, these ties are more likely to exist during the COVID-19 era and the Ukraine-Russia conflict. Numerous coherencies indicate how significant the relationship between the prevalence of various indicators is. However, it is impossible to distinguish between the effects of the two indications with just that information. The analysis of partial coherency must be performed for that reason in the following step.Fig. 2
Wavelet multiple coherency between green and renewable energy and carbon risk

In the literature, previous studies also employ wavelet analysis to illustrate the different relationships at different times and frequencies. For example, similar findings are found between energy consumption and economic growth (Magazzino et al. 2021), between renewable energy consumption as well as technological innovation and CO2 emissions (Adebayo et al. 2022), or between electricity consumption and financial development (Matar 2020).

sec.title: Connected between green and renewable energy and carbon risk during the Russia-Ukraine conflict
sec.p: The above results do not satisfy the needs of people who want to learn about the impact of the Russia-Ukraine conflict on the energy market. Our research applies innovative multivariate wavelet analysis tools to explore Connected between green and renewable energy and carbon risk during the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Figure 4 demonstrates multiple coherencies among renewable and green energy consumption and carbon risk during the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Regarding the multiple coherencies among green bonds, clean energy, and carbon emission futures, Fig. 4a indicates at least three areas with statistically significant coherency. The high-frequency band contains the most significant cycles (relating to cycles of 8.5-day periodicity) and runs from early March 2022 to middle March 2022, from early April 2022 to the end of April 2022, and from early June 2022 to the end of our sample. Figure 2b reveals the multiple coherencies between the solar energy index, envitec biogas, biofuels, geothermal energy, and carbon emission futures. Additionally, at least four areas had statically meaningful coherency, but they were only concentrated in the low-frequency range (from 12 to 64 days), which covered the time from the middle of March to the middle of June 2022, and the high-frequency range (from 6 to 12 days), which covered the time from late February to early march 2022. Interestingly, three regions coexisted from the middle of April 2022 to the middle of May 2022 and from early May 2022 to the middle of June 2022. Our findings suggest a significant environmental impact of renewable energy fluctuation during the Ukraine-Russia conflict based on the interactions between these parameters.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Our article indicated the effects of carbon risk on green and renewable energy during the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The partial wavelet coherency tool was used in this study to analyze the connectedness between these indicators at different frequencies. Moreover, our paper employs the partial wavelet gains tool to determine the strength of that connectedness. We must use an approach that does not need stationary properties because carbon risk dynamics are non-stationary. We can explore cycles of various lengths with MWA techniques. In particular, it is important to note that investment decisions to reach the goal of improving the environment or sustainable development, which combines both goals, are either simple or quick, while action taken by decision-makers is also arranged for the long-term. Therefore, it makes sense to take into consideration relationships in shorter temporal cycles or at greater frequencies, i.e., long-term decisions. At the aforementioned actors, the results in MWA for higher frequencies are especially relevant since they give an understanding of the daily linkages between outcome indicators.

The relationship between green and renewable energy and carbon risk has been examined in earlier studies. They show contradictory results about this connectedness. In this study, we look for the explanation for this correlation in the market for renewable energy, where the lack of long enough data availability prevents similar research from being done. We can examine this problem in depth and offer important insights by utilizing the unique methodology. The multiple coherencies between S&P green bond index, S&P clean energy index, and carbon emission futures suggest that these regions were focused at low frequencies and span from early 2017 to 2018, in the first half of 2020, and from early 2022 to the end of the sample. The coherencies between the solar energy index, Biogas, biofuels, geothermal energy, and carbon emission futures span from early 2020 to middle 2022 in the low-frequency range and span from early 2022 to middle 2022 in the high-frequency range. Our research demonstrates the partial coherencies between these indicators during the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The partial coherency between the S&P green bond index and carbon risk suggests that carbon risk pushes anti-phase connectedness. The partial phase difference S&P global clean energy index and carbon emission futures (from early April 2022 to the end of April 2022) recommend that indicators are in-phase with carbon risk pushing, and the phase (from early May 2022 to middle June 2022) suggests that carbon emission futures are in-phase with S&P global clean energy index pushing. Considering the partial coherency of wind energy and carbon risk, the results show that wind energy caused alterations in carbon risk. It is an adverse connectedness from early March 2022 to the middle of March 2022 and carbon risk pushing anti-phase connectedness from the middle of March 2022 to early April 2022. The partial phase difference between solar power and carbon risk (from middle March 2022 to early April 2022) recommends carbon risk pushing anti-phase connectedness, and the phase (from early April 2022 to middle May 2022) recommends that alterations in solar energy caused alterations in carbon risk, and it is an adverse connectedness. The partial wavelet coherency of biogas and carbon risk recommends that indicators are in-phase with carbon risk pushing. The partial phase-difference between clean fuels and carbon risk (from late February 2022 to the end of March 2022) recommends alterations in clean fuels caused alterations in carbon risk, and it is an adverse connectedness and the phase (from early April 2022 to the end of sample) that indicators are in-phase with carbon risk pushing. The partial phase difference between geothermal energy and carbon risk (from late February 2022 to middle March 2022) recommends that carbon emission futures is in-phase with geothermal energy pushing, and the phase (from middle March 2022 to late April 2022) recommends that indicators are in-phase with carbon risk pushing. The last region (from early May 2022 to middle May 2022) recommends alterations in geothermal energy caused alterations in carbon risk, and it is an adverse connectedness.

The conclusions of our article had significant policy ramifications and suggestions. The findings show that carbon risk may negatively affect renewable and green energy. However, the interlinkages between green and renewable energy and carbon risk are time-varying. Despite carbon risk, the development of green and renewable energy poses environmental protection. Considering the present energy market picture, they should be more adaptable when managing investors' portfolios during the Russia-Ukraine conflict. By reducing or eliminating the impact of carbon risk, the government may make a greater contribution to the development of renewable energy sources and environmental sustainability. Both in the short and long terms, environmental and social sustainability are prerequisites for sustainability. An energy transformation priority policy should be part of the energy development strategy. The development of renewable energy should be the focus of policies concurrently.

Two restrictions should be considered while interpreting our study’s results. First, we used historical data that had solely been gathered for renewable energy. Moreover, our research has not compared the relationship between green energy and carbon risk in developing countries and developed countries. Second, there might be more ways that carbon risk can influence how well the environment performs. Recommendations for policymakers and economists in formulating policies to improve environmental sustainability are anticipated to come from a study that takes these pathways into consideration. Future studies should examine the data sources to learn more about the environmental performance of renewable energy sources in emerging nations.
